Award.AwardTitle: Scholarship Program for Improving Retention of Penn State Change of Location Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to understand and remediate factors that reduce the retention and success of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) students attempting to complete a 2+2 plan at Pennsylvania State University (PSU). The goal is to bring the retention and graduation rates of 2+2 STEM PSU students from other campuses at least into parity with students that begin and remain at the University Park campus of PSU. This is accomplished by implementing a multifaceted advising, career counseling, and mentoring program, combined with $4,000 scholarships that will provide 2+2 students with the support they need to succeed in math and science majors.

The program helps to weld a cadre of students into a community that allows a methodical investigation into the impact of each of the targeted interventions. This knowledge will be incorporated into a long-range plan for making successful strategies and interventions available for all Eberly College of Science students enrolled in the 2+2 plan, so that the project's potential impact reaches approximately one thousand students who will transfer to PSU University Park during the project period. This project is a model for retention efforts in STEM for students moving from community colleges to four-year institutions and the results will be shared broadly with the higher education community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Penn State Science Dean’s Scholars (SDS) program was initiated with the support of this NSF S-STEM grant to provide the proactive advising, mentoring, and support networks, individualized to reflect the backgrounds and personal and academic needs of science students changing campus location in the Penn State 2+2 Plan. This approach brings the evidence based practices from science education literature on effective strategies to improve student retention: at the national level, students who leave science and math report central concerns in assessment and curriculum and a lack of personal support mechanisms.

As a goal of the project, this program was used to bring the retention and graduation rates of Penn State 2+2 Plan science students into alignment with otherwise academically matched cohorts who began at University Park. Participation in the program and scholarship awards included more than 80 undergraduate students over the term of the grant. Students also benefitted from peer mentors, a dedicated academic advisor, and professional development opportunities in a seminar course specifically designed for them. Together, these worked to provide programmatic support and guidance that enabled students to be successful, with graduation rates equal to or exceeding their University Park counterparts.

The principles and programmatic opportunites that were developed using this grant are being applied and extended to the larger population of students who fluidly move between campuses during the undergraduate career at Penn State, and provides a model for supporting student success through transitions.
